title: Former President Carter in Hospital for Surgery
summary: Procedure to relieve pressure on his brain is scheduled for Tuesday morning. ATLANTA-Former President Carter was admitted to a hospital on Monday evening for a surgery to relieve pressure on his brain, caused by bleeding because of his recent falls, his spokeswoman said.

title: Bolivia's Former President Accepts Mexico's Asylum Offer
summary: Security forces work to restore order after violence and looting amid conflicting orders. Former Bolivian President Evo Morales, whose resignation amid allegations of fraud in October's presidential election left his country without a leader and mired in growing chaos, departed Bolivia Monday night on a plane for Mexico, which offered him asylum.

title: U.S. Government Is Tripping Over Itself in Race to Dominate 5G
summary: Different parts of the government are fighting over spectrum space, threatening to undermine the country's efforts. President Trump stood in front of hardhat-wearing cell-tower climbers this spring in the White House and declared deploying a superfast 5G wireless network a national priority.

title: How 5G Could Drive Mobile Sports Betting
summary: Faster wireless service could connect more fans, provide opportunities for fans to bet on games as they watch. The advent of faster 5G wireless service could be a boon for the fledgling U.S. mobile sports-betting industry.

title: 5G Race Could Leave Personal Privacy in the Dust
summary: New networks will collect more data on the physical world. Experts warn public policy hasn't caught up.. Wireless companies racing to build new 5G networks are expected to bring billions of cameras, sensors and other "smart" devices along for the ride, a trend that could spell trouble for personal privacy.

title: In the Race for 5G, Africa Lags Far Behind
summary: Telecom operators say consumer demand doesn't justify the huge investment needed to deploy the new wireless technology. JOHANNESBURG-While the rest of the world races to deploy next-generation 5G wireless technology, Africa is lagging behind, mainly because of poor consumers' inability to pay for fast data services and devices.

title: FAA Eyed Ordering Southwest to Idle 38 Jets Over Records
summary: FAA considered grounding some of the used planes over concerns about gaps in paperwork. U.S. regulators recently considered grounding more than three dozen Southwest Airlines Co. jets because the airline couldn't show that they met all mandatory safety standards, according to government documents.

title: Laura Cooper Told Impeachment Inquiry About Concerns Over Ukraine Aid
summary: In transcript of testimony, Pentagon official describes efforts to free up money. A Pentagon official told House impeachment investigators that a White House budget aide said at a July 26 meeting that nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine was on hold because of President Trump's concerns about corruption in the country.

title: The Court and the Dreamer Pawns
summary: They deserve legal status but judges pre-empted a political compromise.. The Supreme Court leaps again Tuesday into the thicket of executive power when it considers President Trump's rescission of the Obama Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (Daca) program. This is an example of how judicial meddling undermined a political compromise, and the Justices will have to sort the law from the emotive politics.

title: Another Reason Texas Rocks
summary: Lone Star State voters pass new protection against an income tax.. Texas has become one of America's fastest-growing states, thanks in part to its lack of a state income tax. So it was encouraging last week when Lone Star State voters made it even more difficult to impose such a tax.

title: A Democratic Breakout in Bolivia
summary: Evo Morales resigns but he'll use the Cuba-Chávez playbook to return.. No one should shed a tear for the resignation Sunday of authoritarian Evo Morales as President of Bolivia, but the immediate future of that country depends on its ability to hold new elections and reinstate a legitimate government.

title: Europe Wants Your Annuity
summary: Trump officials may fall for the EU's insurance regulation this week.. America's state-based insurance regime has protected policy holders while fostering competition and product diversity. Europe's insurance system-like much else on the Continent-is sclerotic due to excessive regulation. Now the pooh-bahs in Brussels are trying to undermine America's federalist system.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Direct Anger at Police as Violence Flares
summary: A movement that began as opposition to Beijing's sway is now propelled by outrage over police tactics; officers blame protesters for violent actions. HONG KONG-Public anger at Hong Kong's police force has become a driving force behind a protest movement that is increasingly marked by violent confrontations, after beginning as peaceful opposition to Beijing's growing influence over the city's affairs.

title: Lindsey Graham to Trump's Rescue
summary: The senator says impeachment is 'dead on arrival' unless the whistleblower testifies.. Not long ago, anyone who predicted that Sen. Lindsey Graham would become Donald Trump's biggest defender would have been thought certifiably cuckoo.

title: NATO Isn't Dead, but It's Ailing
summary: Macron is right that the alliance needs to adapt to a rapidly changing world.. NATO is brain-dead. So said French President Emmanuel Macron in an interview published last week.

title: 'The Suspect' Review: Collateral Damage
summary: Richard Jewell was the first to spot the deadly bomb at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics-and was rewarded with accusations of being the bomber.. The last thing the FBI needs at the moment is a painstaking re-examination of one of the most embarrassing episodes in its long and mostly effective history. But a new book about the bureau's hunt for the man who planted a bomb at the 1996 Summer Olympics shows the G-men at their bureaucratic worst. The victims were not only the dead and maimed but also a bumbling security guard named Richard Jewell, who was stigmatized for life by the FBI and the media.

title: Warren's '2 Cents' Come at Your Expense
summary: Her levy on wealth would sink stocks, raise interest rates, and confiscate far more than she admits.. Sen. Elizabeth Warren is campaigning for a 2% surtax on anyone's net worth over $50 million and 6% on more than $1 billion. Most discussion of the wealth tax has focused on whether it could generate sufficient revenue to fund Ms. Warren's various spending plans, and the revenue likely would be far less than she projects. But that focus overlooks the ways the massive new tax would harm all Americans.

title: The Gentle Art of Roughhousing
summary: I wouldn't be able to do it if I didn't have grandchildren.. At 78 I should probably be sipping wine with friends in a "senior living community" or gazing at the sunset from a cruise ship. Instead I sit in my daughter's New York apartment, waiting for my 5-year-old grandson to scream "Ninja warrior!" and jump on me.

title: Abortion Extremists Hijack the U.N.
summary: Organizers of the Nairobi Summit attempt to undo the careful consensus forged at Cairo a quarter-century ago.. The governments of Kenya and Denmark and the United Nations Population Fund are attempting to hijack the U.N.'s global population and development work to support an extreme pro-abortion agenda. On Tuesday UNFPA opens the three-day Nairobi Summit, 25 years after the International Conference on Population Development in Cairo.

title: Iraqi Freedom Confronts Iranian Domination
summary: The U.S. has turned toward realpolitik, but it has a strategic interest in backing demonstrators.. Americans long ago lost interest in the democratic experiment they set in motion more than 15 years ago in Iraq-abandoning the "freedom agenda" that was once the heart of U.S. Middle East policy in favor of a realpolitik focused on threats like Iran. Yet while Washington has largely disengaged from domestic politics in Baghdad, the exercise of Iraqi freedom suddenly confronts the Iranian regime with a serious strategic challenge-both to its ambitions for regional hegemony and its own internal legitimacy.

title: NYC Mayor Backs NYPD Officers Who Ticketed Churro Vendor
summary: Street-vendor advocates and some politicians seized on the incident to decry a surge in policing on mass transit. title: Enterprise IT Companies Ride Spending Wave
summary: Businesses are budgeting more for cloud computing, AI and other services, boosting tech firms that provide them. title: Iran Enriching Uranium at Fordow Site, U.N. Agency Says
summary: Tehran makes most serious move yet in its calibrated of breaches of nuclear deal. VIENNA-Iran carried out its threat to enrich uranium at its underground Fordow nuclear site, the United Nations atomic agency said Monday, confirming Tehran's most serious step yet away from the 2015 nuclear deal.

summary: Meeting to include medical professionals 'to come up with an acceptable solution to the Vaping and E-cigarette dilemma'. title: Chile's Government Pledges New Constitution in Bid to Quell Protests
summary: Plan to start process in Congress is met with skepticism among antigovernment demonstrators. SANTIAGO, Chile-President Sebastián Piñera's government said it would move forward with a plan to rewrite Chile's market-friendly, dictatorship-era constitution and replace it with one providing a new social pact, in a bid to quell protests that have raged for almost a month.

title: Bundle Up, New York. An Arctic Blast Is Coming.

summary: Despite claims to consider environmental sustainability, ESG funds invest in Exxon and Occidental Petroleum. Funds with a focus on socially responsible investing are enjoying a record year of inflows. But many such portfolios aren't as clean as investors might expect.

summary: Philip Glass's opera about the pharaoh who abolished Egypt's polytheistic religion is a non-narrative, totally engrossing historical fantasy..

title: Jones Act Protects Shipping for Future War
summary: We would surrender global trade to foreign control if America ended its Jones Act. Foreign subsidies suppress American shipbuilding and distort shipping costs.. Regarding your editorial "'America First'? Kill the Jones Act" (Nov. 4): We would surrender global trade to foreign control if America ended the Jones Act. Foreign subsidies suppress American shipbuilding and distort shipping costs. China, in particular, wants to dominate the 90% of world trade that goes by ship; shipbuilding is a key element of its Belt and Road Initiative.

title: The U.S. Should Accept a Nuclear North Korea
summary: The U.S. can continue banging its head against the denuclearization wall. Or it can assist South Korea's campaign to improve relations with its neighbor to the North.. Sue Mi Terry may very well be right that President Donald Trump has misjudged North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's motives ("North Korea's Strong Hand Against the U.S.," Review, Nov. 2). But U.S. policy on North Korea was adrift long before Mr. Trump reached the White House.

title: The FEA Protests Too Much About the Cost of Charters
summary: There are 300,000 charter school students in Florida. If you are smart enough to do the math, that is $1.2 billion a year that the public school systems in Florida receive for doing nothing.. "Charters: A Drain on Classic Public Schools" (Letters, Oct. 31) by Florida Education Association President Fedrick Ingram is an opinion that needs a rebuttal. What is the real financial impact of charters on Florida's traditional schools? Federal, state and local taxes are where education dollars come from.

title: Electoral College Issue Rises As Real Federalism Declines
summary: Ironically, it is the decline of federalism that has made the Electoral College such an issue in America.. Jason Willick's "Like Trump, Justin Trudeau 'Lost the Popular Vote'" (op-ed, Nov. 2) hits the nail on the head. It is difficult to identify a democratic nation that has a direct election of its president, and for good reason. Direct elections tend to disenfranchise the minority and, as history has shown, a minority that feels disenfranchised can do a great deal of damage. Ironically, it is the decline of federalism that has made the Electoral College such an issue in America. As long as the federal government was small, and most of the governance occurred at the state level where regional preferences could be accommodated, the question of who ran the federal government wasn't such a pressing concern. Today, the one-size-fits-all mentality in Washington is bound to create friction and a heated battle for control over what size that should be.

title: Brexit and Corbyn Bring Labour Back to Its Roots
summary: In terms of what Labour has stood for since its origins under Keir Hardie and others, Mr. Corbyn is hardly a "fringe figure.". title: Can the New Song From 'Frozen 2' Become the Next 'Let It Go'?
summary: The husband-and-wife songwriting team tries to re-create musical magic with 'Into the Unknown'. A follow-up to the Disney princess phenomenon, "Frozen" was always going to be met with mountainous expectations. But when the new sequel, which has already set a record for advance ticket sales, opens on Nov. 22, fans will be looking for more than just a fresh story that stays true to the movie's beloved characters. They'll also be waiting for the song; the one that captures the magic, emotional electricity and world-conquering power of "Let It Go."

summary: Beijing's health-care reforms are giving global pharmaceutical companies better access to the world's second-largest drug market. China's plan to make its health-care system better and more affordable is throwing up opportunities for global drugmakers.

title: Hong Kong's Gravity-Defying Property Market Can't Walk on Air Forever
summary: The city's commercial property market is already hurting from the months of unrest. The housing market will follow.. In his pursuit of the Road Runner, Wile E. Coyote occasionally finds himself running on air, having unknowingly sprinted off the edge of a sheer cliff.
